awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Iron availability and dynamics of an emerging infectious disease: Can a micronutrient cause macro-level outcomes?
awd_abstract_narration:
The element iron plays a key role in the cellular chemistry of nearly all life forms. Surprisingly, while iron is the fourth most abundant element on Earth, it often limits growth and reproduction of organisms because it is insoluble in water. Parasites face a special challenge in acquiring iron because hosts actively sequester it.  To obtain iron, therefore, parasites must take it from host tissues by overcoming an array of host defenses.  Changes in host iron levels alter the dynamics of this struggle; for example, there is a tendency for elevated host iron concentration to cause increased parasite virulence across a variety of infectious diseases, including human diseases.  To understand iron?s role in the dynamics of an emerging amphibian disease, chytridiomycosis, the proposed study will test experimentally the biological effects of host iron bioaccumulation on the likelihood of acquiring and spreading an infectious disease. The project is a novel analysis of a potentially broad mechanism influencing the spread of disease in populations of diverse organisms.

Results from this research could explain the recent emergence of a suite of wildlife diseases, if iron is, as suggested, increasing in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems globally. Throughout the study non-scientists will participate in research and the process of discovery. Researchers will engage elementary school students and adults through innovative, university-sponsored outreach programs such as: "Ask a Biologist", a question and answer resource for K-12 students and teachers; "Graduate Partners in Science Education", an after school science program for 7th and 8th graders; and "SHADES", a mentoring program for underrepresented minorities seeking a degree in science, technology, engineering, or math). These activities will engage the public in scientific inquiry and enrich public education, fostering an appreciation of science and conservation.

Emerging infectious diaseases (EIDs) are a growing challenge in an increasingly globalized world. EIDs pose a threat to global biodiversity, directly threatening communities of susceptible organisms, driving them either to extinction or lowering populations to dangerous levels, which increases risk of extinction. Given the growing occurrence of EIDs, understanding their effects on biodiversity is important.

Amphibians are an excellent model system to study the effects of EIDs on biodiversity since they are the most threatened group of vertebrates.This is due in large part to chytridiomycosis, an infectious disease that affects amphibians across six continents. Caused by the fungal parasite Batrachochytridium dendrobatidis, or Bd, chytridiomycosis is associated with dozens of extinctions and numerous population reductions that leave species vulnerable to other pressures. Bd can infect any member of the class Amphibia, with nearly 300 species tested.

In an environment with one host species, epidemiological theory predicts that a lethal pathogen with no reservoir will eventually decline to extinction. This pattern is not seen with Bd. Several host species have been driven to extinction solely as a result of chytridiomycosis, and the parasite persists even in environments with very few amphibian hosts. This density-independent pattern may be caused by the presence of disease reservoirs. Resistant and tolerant amphibians are the most likely biotic reservoir candidates for Bd. Other biotic reservoirs are possible; for example, Bd infects the gastrointestinal tract of crayfish. The conditions under which Bd colonizes invertebrates are unknown and deserve further study.

Ponds and cattle tanks within the Coconino National Forest in Arizona provided an excellent system to study tinterspecific effects of Bd persistence. These ponds contain two plentiful amphibian species: the Boreal Chorus Frog (Pseudacris maculata) and the Tiger Salamander (Ambystoma tigrinum nebulosum), as well as numerous aquatic insects and crayfish. To understand the dynamics of Bd persistence in this system, the project addressed four main questions using field and laboartory experiments:  

1. Do non-susceptible amphibians function as reservoirs of Bd? 2. Do native and non-native invertebrates host Bd and transmit to amphibians? 3. What conditions allow Bd to survive outside a host? 4. What conditions of host community and environment are most conducive to Bd persistence?

Field sample collection of Pseudacris and Ambystoma skin swabs to determine Bd infection status and strain lineage were conducted over the spring and summer of 2013, 2014, and 2015. Water filters containing environmental DNA were collected year-round to assess Bd prevalence in pond water. Pseudacris were captured for strain isolation and use in laboratory and field experiments. Insects of various orders were collected from ponds and preserved to test for Bd presence. Dragonfly larvae tested positive for Bd.

Lab experiments were attempted to assess interspecies Bd transmission dynamics between Pseudacris and Ambystoma. These experiments were unsuccessful due to the use of an unsuitable strain and will be repeated.

Field experiments were conducted in spring of 2014 and 2015 using sentinel Pseudacris collected in 2013. These animals were placed in enclosures within breeding choruses in ponds to assess indirect, intraspecific Bd transmission and prevalence. These experiments demonstrated indirect Bd transmission, an important advance.

Lab challenge experiments on larval mosquitoes were conducted to test if Bd can infect aquatic insects. Results showed no evidence of Bd infection. This species is not a carrier of Bd, also an advance given how common mosquito larvae are.
